item.title: Measure
item.description:
Motivation and Definition

We would like a map $\mu:\pow(\R^n)\to[0,\infty]$, called a measure, that assigns to each $A\subeq\R^n$ its ‘volume’ that is invariant under the \ref[action]{group_action} of $\Isom\R^n$. This turns out to be impossible (for good reason; see \ref[non-measurable sets of $\R$]{measures_on_reals#non-measurability}), so we instead restrict to special subsets of $\R^n$ which are in some sense ‘constructible’.


  If anything, \ref[open]{topology} sets in $\R^n$ (or for convenience, in $[0,1]$) must be measurable, and hence so must their complements and (finite) unions. We can strengthen this by requiring that countable unions of measurable sets remain measurable, for then we can take limits.
